p: The first step of this process involves ALA conversion into EPA, which is an active metabolic product. This is performed through a double bond formation at the sixth and fifth position (by ∆6- and ∆5-desaturase catalysis) and double bond elongation at the sixth position (∆6-elongase). Then, EPA can be metabolized into DHA via ∆5-elongation and ∆4-desaturation [ 22]. The above process is limited, and the only organs capable of these conversions include the liver, cerebrovascular lumen, and astroglial cells [ 33, 34].
